courses.description: As the first in a series of six language courses, this course invites students without prior knowledge of Italian to explore the basic features of the Italian language. Supported by audiovisual aids, students will receive intensive practice in spoken and written Italian through interactive class work, homework and online exercises. They will become familiar with the basic concepts of Italian grammar and learn how to interact in some simple everyday situations.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken ITAL2000,2001,2050,3000,3001,3002,3050 or 3051
courses.learning_outcomes: The students at the end of the course will be able to have a correct pronunciation of the language, getting familiar with its different features. They will be able to have a basic conversation and oral understanding about various everyday situations, such as introducing oneself and others, greeting, asking and giving information, etc. The same skills will be developed for the written language (reading and writing), and the course will also transmit to the learners a good knowledge of the Italian culture, and a basic knowledge of the country and its lifestyle.

courses.description: This course offers information about Italian geography, modern history, political institutions, education, economics, and social and cultural life with special emphasis on Italian culture and artistic heritage. No knowledge of Italian is required.

courses.subject: ITAL
courses.title: Italian II
courses.description: Building on the knowledge acquired in ITAL1000, this course aims to further develop students’ ability to communicate in Italian in various everyday situations. It also seeks to give students a taste of Italian culture and invites them to explore cultural differences. Through intensive practice students will develop more confidence in interacting in Italian while further expanding and solidifying their understanding of the basic grammar and pronunciation patterns.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
1. Not for students who have taken ITAL2001,2050,3000,3001,3002,3050 or 3051 
2. Prerequisite: ITAL1000
courses.learning_outcomes: The students at the end of the course will have enforced the correct pronunciation, getting much more familiar with its different features. They will be able to lead a conversation about practical common situations, such as asking for and giving directions, talking about family members and about past events, getting and giving recommendations, etc. The same skills will be developed for the written language (reading and writing), and the course will also continue to transmit to the learners a good knowledge of the Italian culture, and a good of the country and its lifestyle.

courses.subject: ITAL
courses.title: Italian III
courses.description: This course aims to further enhance students' communication skills in the four language domains listening, speaking, reading and writing. Students are expected to communicate confidently in a wider range of social interactions including more formal situations and simple professional contexts as well as reporting past events and sharing experience. At the end of this course, students will have completed a proficiency level comparable to level A1 of the Common European Framework of Reference for Languages (CEFR).
courses.enrollment_requirement:
1. Not for students who have taken ITAL3000,3001,3002,3050 or 3051
2. Prerequisite: ITAL2000 or 2050
courses.learning_outcomes: The students at the end of the course will have definitely enforced their skills developed in the previous beginners' courses (pronunciation, conversation, understanding, reading and writing). They will enrich their linguistic knowledge with the capability of interacting in more various situations, through the acquisition of more ways of saying and idioms, typical of the Italian language. They will be able to express feelings (happiness, disappointment, gratitude, etc…), and to describe correctly common habits, events and people in the past, using a “new” past tense (imperfetto), which mostly reflects typical Italian attitudes and way of thinking.

courses.description: ( Please read the Study Scheme Note.) This is a summer intensive Italian language course for beginners, covering the full syllabus of ITAL1000 and 2000.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken ITAL1000,2000,2001,3000,3001,3002,3050 or 3051
courses.learning_outcomes: The students at the end of the course will be able to have a correct pronunciation of the language, getting familiar with its different features. They will be able to have a basic conversation and oral understanding about various everyday situations, such as introducing oneself and others, greeting, asking and giving information, etc….The same skills will be developed for the written language (reading and writing), and the course will also transmit to the learners a good knowledge of the Italian culture, and a basic knowledge of the country and its lifestyle. And the second part of the course is a continuation based on studying the language used in everyday situations, and the linguistic syllabus includes lessons on past tense, direct and indirect object pronouns, some more irregular verbs in the present tense, a further overview on articled prepositions, adjectives in the superlative form, modal verbs and some common adverbs. The learning process will be enhanced by group work and audio-visual aids.

courses.description: This course aims at increasing students' communicative fluency in oral and written Italian. Using a variety of classroom activities and multimedia, students will build up their competence in the four language domains listening, speaking, reading and writing. Through intensive practice they will be able to communicate in a wide range of social situations with the appropriate awareness of the pragmatic rules involved. Students receive guidance in the process of composing longer texts displaying a range of registers and styles relating to past, present and future events.

courses.subject: ITAL
courses.title: Italian V
courses.description: This course focuses on the further development of communication skills in Italian with emphasis on the expression of personal views and the training of argumentative strategies. The course will also engage students in critical reflections on various aspects of life in Italian-speaking countries and their own social environment. Students will be guided to analyze various types of data to support their views. They will learn how to express their wishes and aspirations using the appropriate registers.

courses.subject: ITAL
courses.title: Italian VI
courses.description: This course builds on the knowledge acquired through previous Italian language courses. It aims at leading students to a proficiency level comparable to the threshold from A2 to B1 of the Common European Framework for Languages (CEFR), becoming “independent users” of Italian. To achieve this goal, students will be encouraged to work project-based through independent or collaborative work with their peers. At the end of this course students will have mastered the most important grammar features of Italian and be able to communicate effectively in a wide range of everyday situations and a number of professional contexts. They will be able to use their oral and written language skills to relate to, reflect on and analyze past and current issues involving the Italian-speaking societies.

courses.feedback_evaluation: Our language programme highly values students’ feedback and comments and is happy to use them for reflection on our teaching and improvement. Students are very welcome to provide comments and feedback on the course any time to their course teacher or the course level coordinator through email or in personal conversation. In addition, students’ feedbacks will be collected in the middle of the term through an open-end questionnaire and the teacher will discuss the feedbacks in class and make improvements if necessary. The course will also follow the university’s course evaluation exercise at the end of the term, and students’ feedbacks will be used for future course planning and teaching.

courses.subject: ITAL
courses.title: Italian V & VI
courses.description: This is a summer intensive Italian language course, covering the full syllabus of ITAL3001 and 3002.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
1.Not for students who have taken ITAL3001 or 3002
2.Pre-requisite: ITAL3000 or 3050
courses.learning_outcomes: At the end of the course the students will be able to have a correct pronunciation of the language, as well as getting familiar with its different features. They will be able to have a conversation and oral understanding about various everyday situations such as report health problems, give health and sport advice, try to convince someone, talk about the future, express wishes, express disappointment, making comparisons, etc. The same skills will be developed for the written language (reading and writing); The course will also transmit to the learners a good knowledge of the Italian culture and a knowledge of the country and its lifestyle.
courses.course_syllabus:
Lesson
Speech Acts
Grammar
Culture
Lezione 4
Do you want to come?
- Make a proposal
- Accept or reject a proposal
- Motivate a refusal
- Book an appointment
- Book a theater ticket by phone
Stare+gerundio
, direct pronouns and verb
avere (ce l’ho),
the concordance of the past participle with direct object pronouns, the adverbs
già/non…ancora
, the position of direct and indirect pronouns with verbs at the infinitive, relative pronouns
che
and
cui.
Good manners in public places in Italy.
Lezione 5
Have a nice trip!
- Ask for something in a polite way
- Show interest on listen to someone
- Show happiness after a proposal
- Express surprise and displeasure
- Inquire about something
- Ask the duration of a trip and the price
Use of
volere
with
imperfetto
tense, verbs s
apere
and
conoscere
with present perfect and
imperfetto
, use of present perfect and
imperfetto
, verb
volerci.
What is
Ferragosto
? History and traditions of an all Italian festivity.
Lezione 6
At the table
- Give advice
- Interact on a social network
- Express needs
- Talk about food and eating habits
- Comment about food taste and express opinion
Quello che
, imperative irregular, negative imperative, verb
servire
, the position of the pronouns with the imperative, informal irregular imperatives.
Festival and traditions in Italy.
Lezione 7
How are you?
- Report health problems
- Describe symptoms
- Confirm a possibility
- Give health advice
- Give advice on sport activities
- Talk about your relationship
- Try to convince someone
The imperative (Lei and voi), the negative imperative (Lei and voi), the position of the pronouns with the imperative, comparative and superlative of buono and bene, nouns in tore and ista, some nouns with irregular plural.
Italian football, the national sport.
Lezione 8
Dear Doctor
- Talk about the future
- Express wishes and intentions
- Write an application for a job
- Express assumptions
- Talk about work and working conditions
Simple future tense, verbs bisogna/metterci with the meaning of needing time, the hypothetical period of reality (se+present or future), pronouns la and le.
Italy, a country of “Doctors”.
Lezione 10
Home sweet home
- Express disappointment
- Describe an apartment
- Express needs and wishes
- Make arguments in favor of something
- Making comparisons
The adjective bello, the present subjunctive of verbs in are/ere/ire, the present subjunctive of some irregular verbs, use of subjunctive to express necessity, hope and personal opinipions, the comparative più…di/che, adverb magari.
This is how Italy lives, types of houses compared.
